review_title: Good learning experience but not without the headache
pros: Good learning experience, ability to venture out and explore other roles
cons:
Management needs a serious facelift. It seems like there is one goal and it’s to meet the budget so they can reap the financial rewards. Lots of leadership roles step on each other’s feet. The organization stresses diversity, inclusion and equity but reward the biggest offenders with promotions, awards, and raises. If you want to succeed here, best be prepared to learn who the rule makers are (it’s not always who you think), plant your nose firmly up their rear, and become the quintessential yes person. Anyone truly committed to their role and the greater good will not succeed based on merit alone. It’s a pity but it is how it is.
Advice to Management
When employees reach out with serious concerns and warnings that things need to improve, pay heed. They know more than you (suck it up and accept this as fact. It doesn’t make you any less of a leader if you know how to leverage the intel). Otherwise, you’ll see a continued exodus of your best talent. Treat your reports right and they might stick with you longer.
Helpful (1)

review_title: Good enough but there are way better companies/industries offering competitive pay in the DC metro area
pros: Nice colleagues. Generally nice people. Pepco building in Chinatown - good choices for lunch/happy hour.
cons:
Industry: Dealing with utilities (especially a hated brand like Pepco) isn't the most exciting, fun, or satisfying.
Pay: Much better being a contract employee. Lost significant amount of pay after joining as a full-time employee. No perks or competitive benefits package could make up for the loss in compensation.
Benefits: Sub-par. Only one option for medical.
Work/Life Balance: Probably the worst part of the job. Evening, weekends, holidays are often disrupted because employees must perform "storm duties".
When major storms hit, employees are expected to travel through dangerous storm conditions to work on-site from Bethesda storm center and work 12 hour shifts.
Advice to Management
Trust younger and newer employees with suggestions about how to make changes and be open to trying new things - especially regarding newer business areas like social media.

review_title: Lost between past, present, and future
pros: When it shines, it shines brighter than any public utility in the country. Exelon does a ton right. There is tremendous opportunity to learn about all sectors in the electric utility space, and I mean any part. Exelon is involved from start to finish in the life-cycle of electricity, from production to distribution, to innovation they have it all. Easily a company one could spend an entire career at. Great work-life balance, decent benefits.
cons:
Unfortunately with all the good the company does right, it does just as much, if not more wrong for the employees. Exelon touts their benefits and pay compensation like sites like Glassdoor and LinkedIn don't exist. These are middle of the road at best if not subpar at this point. The biggest problem is career stagnation and outright mismanagement. There are a ton of directors walking around at Exelon that simply don't belong in that role. Nepotism is real, even if senior management denies it. The company also suffers from a ton of roadblocks at middle management positions forcing young talent to look elsewhere for career advancement.
Advice to Management
Revamp performance reviews and be honest yourselves. The company has a bright future, smart executive leaders, but a dense fog at the director to upper manager levels that is preventing the best and brightest from rising to the occasion.
Helpful (7)
Exelon Response

review_title: New leadership train wrecked a good company
pros: Pay matches the market, good bonus structure and work from home flexibility.
cons:
First 4 yrs were ok, the last year plus went down hill. It was a good company to work for until the new VP came in. Since then, morale sucks. Employees are continually complaining about unfair treatment across multiple departments. Groups that did not operate 24/7 were held to 24/7 SLAs then questioned why they didn't met the SLA, seriously. Then automation was forced on teams with no coding skill only to take 6 months to develop a team to help. Matrix are now the one stop shop for all judgment, which can be fine, but the reports are broke so groups have gotten beat up over and over for false reports. 

On call is horrible, not tiered properly and vastly different between departments.

You WILL put in a LOT of hours. Work life balance is talked about, but it’s WAY out of balance for most. If you think a 60 hr work week is balance, then you know what Exelon means by work balance. On the other side of the coin, there are people that don't do a thing and somehow manange to fly under the radar. 

The company flip flops on hiring contractors then follows up with talk about subbing out work continuously. It’s as if they don't know what they want and someone new comes in and thinks they can save a buck. In the end, it’s a yo-yo approach that only stresses employees. 

Managers are told of the dissatisfaction, but it seems they are limited in power. From the bottom looking up, others around the new management are just yes people while the lower lv is not recognized like years past.
Advice to Management
Don't beat employees into 'improvement'
Helpful (5)
Exelon Response

Thank you for sharing your feedback and giving us the opportunity to improve
advice_to_mgmt: Don't beat employees into 'improvement'

review_title: Great mission and desire to push industry forward; middle management is lacking
pros:
-Corporate vision is progressive - accelerating a clean energy future
-Strong and leading brand in power sector; corporate giant
-Strong efforts in innovation and transformation initiatives
-Competitive pay and benefits
cons:
-Talent acquisition strategy for professional positions seems lacking and unintentional; does not at all feel like you're working with the best and brightest
-Talent development programs are very lacking; mostly ad hoc, trial-by-fire training and learning
-Too many initiatives without strong, capable leadership and clear vision embedded throughout the company
-Bureaucratic, hierarchical structure is slow to adapt to changes and emergent opportunities
Advice to Management
Radically improve talent acquisition and talent development. I want to be working with the best of the best, and I want to continuous training to be the best of the best. Partner with the top universities across the country; be more intentional and careful with recruiting. Identify and root out mediocrity.

You can't achieve your strategy of becoming a cutting edge, innovative leader in this transforming industry without strong talent at all levels of the organization (not just the top).

pros: Exelon markets itself as a leader in the future of energy. In fact, they are. The bulk of their energy portfolio is nuclear which is a zero emission fuel source which will be vital as we (hopefully) move away from fossil fuels. Additionally, they sell potential staff on competitive benefits, growth opportunity, and diversity. Generally, these are catch-all phrases that sound great on paper but are never put into action. Exelon legitimately does have above-market pay and benefits. Base comp, retirement, etc. are all above market and they also leverage their size to get some really cool fringe benefits as well! Further, there is ample opportunity for growth within your department and company-wide. They offer analytics, learning modules, tuition assistance, and plenty of inter-departmental groups. Lastly, diversity is key here. Exelon aims to mimic the communities they are located within so you truly do get a wide range of backgrounds, races, ethnicity, and just overall personalities here. It makes our company great.
cons:
Sometimes due to company size things move a little slow and there can also be unfair work balance between teams.
Advice to Management
Keep it up! My only advice would be to modernize some processes (and tech) and teach teams to delegate work within so that everyone stays busy and motivated.

pros: Good pay. I definitely felt challenged with the work I was doing. My direct supervisors were lenient and trusted me to get my work done.
cons:
I was a staff aug contractor (engineering) at a nuclear power plant. Exelon began to change rules for staff aug contractors almost every month. This was sometime in the year 2015. They implemented a rule that contractors had to take 90 days off for every 2 year period. When I tried to come back after my 90 day period, I found that I was on a "do not hire list". The people I worked with and managers tried to understand why I was put on this list. Apparently, it was from the security department in corporate office. No one could get an answer. A few times I called the security department, but they never could answer the question about why I was on this list. Some did not even bother to call me back. I understand companies have a "do not hire" list, but it was uncalled for in my situation since I was one of their top employees and did nothing wrong. They did not even have the decency to help me understand why. I actually suspect it was done illegally.
On two separate occasions after 2016 someone from Exelon called me to work as a staff aug at their nuclear power plant since I have a good reputation in the industry. The same thing resurfaced. The managers that wanted to hire me also did not get a valid reason.
Advice to Management
Making up rules as you go creates an uncertain work environment. This pushes out good employees. When you put someone on a "do not hire" list at least of the decency to tell the employee why.
Helpful (5)

advice_to_mgmt: Making up rules as you go creates an uncertain work environment. This pushes out good employees. When you put someone on a "do not hire" list at least of the decency to tell the employee why.

pros: Competitive pay rate. Also the company has an emphasis on career progression. Also, they are attempting to cut the administrative burdens that plague engineers, although with extremely limited success.
cons:
The staff has been severely cut, through retirements and normal attrition, in an effort to reduce overhead. But no work has been cut. Engineers are stretched very thin and often work long hours. What makes the situation worse is the lack of knowledge retention. We have lost a lot of very smart folks with 30 plus years of experience to retirement but there is very little effort to transfer their knowledge and experience to new engineers. This means even when we hire new engineers they are essentially useless. All this creates an environment that sees an almost unheard of turnover rate. Since I have been at this specific job (5ish years), about 2 dozen engineers have quit systems and design engineering or taken jobs elsewhere in the company. 

Lastly, while there are great career progression opportunities, they come with a significant increase in hours. Most of the lowest level supervisors put 60 hours in on a regular, non event work week. Work to reduce that have not been fruitful.
Advice to Management
When new policies are dreamed up, also enact a workable change management plan. If you reduce workers, you have to reduce work otherwise it doesnt make a difference.

pros: Pay, pay, pay; Culture; Diversity and inclusion; great potential to grow personally and professionally; Jon security is a non issue, they very rarely lay off or terminate employees; huge emphasis on safety; The company invests a lot in its work force: any training you can imagine from leadership, to negotiating, etc. Most departments are very well resourced. Overtime is plentiful in busy departments.
cons:
Rigid leadership from director level and above. Some departments are not overworked so have challenges like being clique-ey, other departments (mine) are very very busy and employees need to work 50+ hrs a week to stay on top of workload. Innovation is sorely needed, and although senior leadership understands this and are vocal about supporting it somewhere along the line the execution falls apart. Instead of the vertical management model, there needs to be a lot more of horizontal structure, with the highest level executives working in the trenches with individual contributers and owning innovation initiatives.
Advice to Management
More horizontal leadership structure is needed. Base pay should be increased for those with high volume of work. There are dozens of software systems we work on, there is a sore need to streamline and invest in technology that enhances communication between all software systems.

pros: Good benefits, competitive pay, lots of opportunities for technology enhancement and implementation strategies. Very knowledgeable staff, with great online material available to help you get integrated.
cons:
As a newly hired manager (18 months); the only con is that our leadership has a culture that makes it difficult for them to accept or adapt to new ideas surrounding IT & telecom solutions and synergistic strategies, the culture has the mentality of “we’ve been doing it like this for the past 20-30 years” or this is a utility - “we move slower than your typical Fortune 100”.
Advice to Management
Keep up the focus on the OCIO strategy and initiatives; they seem to be heading in the right direction for IT. Reach out to your new hires, ask them for ideas and input. The idea of 10-15 year technology lifecycle is 1980’s thinking. For our. Sr Execs - if Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures is a part of your roadmap - your IT Telecomm should be an agile, adaptable world class infrastructure to ensure synergies and systems integration within 18 months ( not the current model of 5+ years) we need to get ahead of our competition. Embrace technology, treat it as a core function, it is what will make Exelon the benchmark for utilities of the future. I look forward to being part of a dynamic team.

review_title: Very Political and lacks good leadership
pros: Great clients, pay, health benefits, maternity leave, generous PTO time, some co-workers mostly in other departments
cons:
Extremely political. You can be valued by your clients and a hard worker but if you are on leaderships target list they will treat you horribly and mkae you feel terrible. Leadership is on Facebook for hours but yet rewarded with a promotion. Yelling at your clients also gets you promoted. Leadership, managers do no develop their employees.
Advice to Management
Develop your employees and don't tell them they are doing a great job and then one second later try and push them out the door. Exelon use to be a great company to work for but really lacking inspirational leadership. All leadership cares about is hitting their big bonus at year end.

November 12, 2018 – Talent Acquisition
Thank you for sharing this feedback. We value your input and would like to understand more so that we can work to ensure that Exelon is a great workplace for all of our employees. We encourage you to contact the 24 Hour Ethics hotline or your own HR representative to provide us with the opportunity to understand your concerns and make improvements wherever possible. Fostering employee development and creating transparency around the performance management process is a current focus area for our HR and Leadership teams. With the recent transformation of our performance management process, employees are now equipped with more modern and simplified tools, processes, and technologies that are specifically designed to aid their development, while encouraging an inclusive culture through real-time dialogue. pros: Pay, benefits, and retirement benefits are above average.
cons:
I have been with Exelon as a member of management for several years and am extremely frustrated. I have interviewed for several positions out there only to be disappointed time after time. In almost every instance I have been the most qualified, educated, or experienced candidate but was not selected. I am a solid employee that is dedicated, loyal, and respected by my peers. So, why do I keep getting passed over? It's primarily because of nepotism or the good old boy system that gets me every time or the excuse that they "had" to find a job for an employee. In the two times that has happened to me, the person beating me out had a parent working for Exelon....Hmmm....shocker. Compensation is based on who you know and not experience or past accomplishments. My advice is that you shouldn't expect anything based on hard work because it doesn't matter. What matters is if your mommy or daddy or buddy works there. If so, definitely apply to Exelon.
Advice to Management
Seriously reevaluate all HR hiring and compensation practices. It's extremely common for people to get passed over due to nepotism or the buddy system. Compensation and pay level promotions are waived for some but not for all.

review_title: Good Benefits, however it's key to get a job at the right grade level because promotions are hard to come by
pros:
1. Good Benefits with Pension Plan, 15 days vacation, 4 Personal Days, 5 sick days, Stock Options, Company Bonus where lowest Grade Level (E02) receives 10%; However HMO health insurance seems pricey at about $450/mo for parent and child
2. Lots of projects for Project Managers. Many are interesting, challenging and innovative.
3. Able to work from home 3 days a week on some Nuclear teams.
4. The employees, for the most part, are friendly and great to work with across IT and Nuclear
cons:
1. If you don't enter the company at the correct Grade Level, there is no opportunity for a promotion on the same team or Division, unless someone leaves a position at the next Grade Level. You have to apply for a promotion when a position of interest at the next Grade Level opens anywhere in the company. I have received many accolades and recognitions for my work, but cannot be given a promotion. Most positions at the next grade level for project management require travel which is not an option for me. Also, there is little turnover in the company overall, so positions at the next level take a while to open up.
2. No Program Manager or Portfolio Manager positions
3. No PMO; Although a new group is starting that will provide guidance on Project reporting via HP PPM, and best practices. It will not include resource load planning for projects across IT.
4. The IT Project Management effort is underestimated and understaffed causing Project Managers to work 50 - 65 hours a week in Nuclear Division. Project Coordinators are needed to support Project Managers but these positions do not exist.
5. Resource load planning for projects at the IT level is not performed. Too many priority projects across several IT departments are implemented at the same time requiring the same resources, which cause those resources to work over 50 hours a week.
Advice to Management
I recommend IT management take into account resource loads as priority projects are scheduled. The schedule should take into account the resources in all IT Departments that are required to work on the projects, so that resources are not overloaded and additional resources can be secured prior to the projects starting. Many employees are getting burn out because IT Management is not doing this.
Helpful (5)
Exelon Response
November 12, 2018 – Talent Acquisition
Thank you for sharing your experience. Given the nature of our business, certain departments may indeed require longer hours at times. As you noted, we offer a highly competitive compensation and benefits program designed to reward our employees for achieving excellent operational performance and outstanding financial results. We want to ensure that Exelon also provides a healthy environment for all employees and encourage you to leverage the resources available to employees via the Work/Life Benefits portal, or contact your HR representative to further discuss your concerns. Thank you for being part of the Exelon Family
advice_to_mgmt: I recommend IT management take into account resource loads as priority projects are scheduled. The schedule should take into account the resources in all IT Departments that are required to work on the projects, so that resources are not overloaded and additional resources can be secured prior to the projects starting. Many employees are getting burn out because IT Management is not doing this.

review_title: Political.... Its who you worked for!
pros: Great benefits, nice quite environment. Projects were satisfying, and deadlines were realistic.
cons:
If you did not work for Mayor Daily or Emanual's office or another governmental department in Chicago, you will find it hard to climb past basic management. This is extremely political, not what you know but who you know or who you worked for in the past. They work on projects that politicians want and not what consumers want.
Very few leaders were qualified for their positions (not bashing them personally, just professionally.. they were pretty nice people in general.) Our boss used to leave a digital tape recorder on top of her purse so she could record the discussions in the adjacent cubicles. (Yes I have photos). She was not qualified for her role, and knew the rest of the team outshined her. The projects are fine to work on, and the deliverable's are weak, as we only needed to justify our existence. There is no consumer or governmental pressure to actually reduce costs and no competitive forces for reducing the pricing. There is a lot of cost justification, and little to no discussion about cost savings or providing pricing benefits to the consumer.
Advice to Management
I found my opinions did not count while I was there. This would fall on deaf ears (its hard to hear criticism when you are at the Cubs game or the United Center over the crowds) The problem is the executive team and the leadership. Keep striving for justification!
Helpful (2)
Exelon Response
August 8, 2018 – Talent Acquisition
Thank you for sharing this feedback. We strive to provide an employment experience built on inclusion, trust, and collaboration, and are disheartened to hear that your experience did not align with our efforts to ensure that Exelon is a great place to work for all of our employees
advice_to_mgmt: I found my opinions did not count while I was there. This would fall on deaf ears (its hard to hear criticism when you are at the Cubs game or the United Center over the crowds) The problem is the executive team and the leadership. Keep striving for justification!

review_title: This ship is sinking ... look elsewhere
pros: Flexible schedule and a paycheck every two weeks
cons:
I’m convinced all the good reviews on GlassDoor for Exelon are writing by Exelon HR. Here is the truth:
Pay inequality for women is common. 
Sexism is common. 
Unbelievable red tape to accomplish anything (IT, renewing contracts, etc).
Management leaves with no replacement in sight and they leave the peons to do all their work for no compensation. 
Very high turnaround because everyone who comes in realizes this company is a mess and they get out while they can. 
No advancement unless it’s through brown nosing and nepotism. 
Company consistently disregards the talent and expertise of its low level employees and promotes inexperienced twits. 
Management across departments is known to promise full time positions to contractors and it never pans out.
Advice to Management
Stop buying companies and ruining them!
Helpful (11)
Exelon Response
June 15, 2018 – Talent Acquisition
Thank you for sharing your feedback. We value your input and would like to understand more so that we can make sure that Exelon is a great workplace for all of our employees. Please contact the 24 Hour Ethics hotline or your own HR representative to provide us with the opportunity to understand your concerns and make improvements wherever possible. In December 2016, we took the national Equal Pay Pledge to publicly declare a commitment to equal pay. We were pleased that the results of an independent third-party analysis of Exelon's pay practices showed no systemic pay differences between men and women in comparable jobs with similar levels of experience. That said, we will continue to identify and promote other opportunities – such as expanding our paid family leave policy and joining the United Nations Women's HeForShe campaign – to assist in closing the national gender wage gap and helping to ensure equitable treatment of all employees. Enhancing employee development is another critical focus area for our HR and Leadership teams. The recent transformation of our performance management process equips employees with more modern and simplified tools, processes, and technologies that are specifically designed to foster professional development and build an inclusive culture through real-time dialogue. We hope to have the opportunity to speak with you further

Exelon has a Policy Against Discrimination and a Policy Against Harassment that prohibit discrimination against employees and applicants for employment by any person, including supervisors, co-workers, customers, suppliers, or vendors. Exelon also prohibits retaliation against any employees or applicants for employment for raising issues of discrimination or for their lawful participation in a matter involving an allegation of discrimination. Diversity & Inclusion is one of our core values, a business imperative, and a moral obligation that we believe benefits everyone from employees to customers to shareholders. pros: The people you work with are mostly pretty good. You have many managers that shouldn't be managers but no one else will take the job because it's horrible pay for huge responsibility.
cons:
The amount of cons is far too long to list. They will give goals to hit and if you go above and beyond they won't give you a bonus that matches what you earned. This year they just took away over 50% of ComEds yearly bonus just because the Exelon board could, no actual reason was given. ComEd, not sure of other companies under Exelon, is known in the electrical industry for using and abusing their employees. One thing that should be under the pro is if you work for them a couple years anyone in the industry will hire you because they know you'll think their company is like heaven. Exelon HR is purely corporate oriented they couldn't care less how employees are treated. Health insurance keeps skyrocketing every year. Now new hires don't even get supplemental insurance when they retire and no pension anymore. If you're young and talented DO NOT waste your career with Exelon/ComEd. There are so many power companies that treat their employees far better. I know because I have many friends throughout the industry. Unfortunately I'm stuck with them until children graduate high school. This is a company that is going downhill. They will not pay you what you deserve and they never stop taking away what you've earned. Every year they chip away and give you less and less but want you to work more and harder. You have Sr VPs who are control freaks and who are nuts. You have people in positions like directors and high level managers that are only in the job because no one else wants the jobs so they constantly promote their least talented. The talented employees are too smart to take on higher level jobs with greater responsibility for almost no benefit in pay or any other aspect. Every position except if you're in the union is under paid and over worked. If you need a job it pays the bills, if you're starting your career only work for them if it's your only option.
Advice to Management
The management is a joke, no advice will turn this company around, it's a sinking ship.
Helpful (1)
Exelon Response
September 24, 2018 – Talent Acquisition
Thank you for sharing your feedback. We value your input and would like to understand more so that we can make sure that Exelon is a great workplace for all of our employees. Please contact the 24 Hour Ethics hotline or your own HR representative to provide us with the opportunity to understand your concerns and make improvements wherever possible. In December 2016, we took the national Equal Pay Pledge to publicly declare a commitment to equal pay. We were pleased that the results of an independent third-party analysis of Exelon's pay practices showed no systemic pay differences between men and women in comparable jobs with similar levels of experience. Enhancing employee development is another critical focus area for our HR and Leadership teams. The recent transformation of our performance management process equips employees with more modern and simplified tools, processes, and technologies that are specifically designed to foster professional development and build an inclusive culture through real-time dialogue. We are disheartened to hear that you have had such experience while with us, and we hope to have the opportunity to speak with you further
advice_to_mgmt: The management is a joke, no advice will turn this company around, it's a sinking ship.

Let up a little. Allow your managers and supervisors to have a life and not have to respond to work 7 days a week.

pros: The pay is decent. Competitive for the sort of work. Benefits are good too. The people I work with are willing to work with you to learn
cons:
Beware relocation package and bonuses. If you leave before 2 years you'll have to pay it back. They also lied about the job. Once you're on site then reveal the truth; system engineering is called system manager. If you like administrative jobs, then it's perfect, but it is NOT engineering. I can't stress that enough. Morale is incredibly low. I believe because of the 2 cons I just gave. The software used is incredibly cumbersome; it's honeslty the hardest part of the job and it isn't particularly hard.
Advice to Management
Don't advertise system manager falsely. Also let people leave without destroying them financially. Morale would improve and people who want to be there will stay. Better yet, actually let engineers engineer; let us build prototypes and look to improving our equipment instead of outsourcing it to vendors for the littlest things.

review_title: Great company working to evolve and cares about their employees
pros: Exelon is a passionate company that truly cares about the service we provide to our customers. The company is looking for ways to innovate technology internally for our employees and externally for our customers. In addition Exelon's compensation and benefits packages are some of the best in the industry. There is a ton of opportunity for internal growth and movement into new fields and different operating companies.
cons:
Hours can be demanding when project work needs to be completed, but that should be expected. It can take sometime to get contracts, projects work, and decisions made, but again in such a large organization in the nuclear space it is important to have the right checks and balances in place that create this.
Advice to Management
Continue to focus on our culture and employees. It is important to not only evolve as a company for our external customers, but also for our employees. It has been great to see offices being more progressive and flexible; even if it is the small things like allowing jeans in the office or working remote when there are no in person meetings that day.

review_title: Great place to start your next career
pros:
Exelon is a fortune 100 company offering an absolutely Awesome culture, best and most comprehensive benefits. I can honestly say I love my job, and our workgroup all the way from our VP down thru the Directors, Managers, Supervisor and our workgroup

If you want a career where you are appreciated, valued and want to make a difference... Exelon is the place for you. My only regret is that I didn't' jump from my former employer and go to Exelon sooner!

The workplace is great, fun people encouraging work life balance. Leadership not only listens to employees they actively solicited input, support creativity, nurture innovation, career development and advancement. Employees are easy to work with and very talented. Teamwork and collaboration drive our success. Everyone is passionate, down to earth

Exelon is community focused, encourages and actively enables employees to give back to our communities and puts its money where it mouth is. As employees volunteer time and money Exelon gives additional bonuses to that company. 

Finally, the on-boarding is very comprehensive and implemented well! Everything from HR thru your new job duties, goals, roles, responsibilities, procedures, and work flow are documented, easy to follow and easy to find. Exelon has an awesome company and employee portal!
cons:
(While this may be a con for the employee... it is a big pro for our customers)
Expect occasional long hours and an emergency response role. Work load and hours can be very demanding at times but there are opportunities for work life balance. 

We often have meetings and work thru lunch, however our management team appreciates our hard work and extra efforts by providing great meals

I work in downtown Philadelphia. And I dreaded considering a long commute into the city. It was the primary reason I didn't consider an Exelon career sooner. Now that I have been working here for just under a year. I have come to appreciate the flexibility our management team provides. They offer state of the are video conferencing tools and are very understanding and supportive with flexible schedules and reporting locations. 

I can honestly say the pros far out weigh the cons!
Advice to Management
Continue the great work already being done. A sincere thank you to our leadership... I know you are listening. You many want to think about a program to encourage employees to help recruit other employees from their previous work life. It is easy to sell the benefits of working for Exelon and it might help spark additional innovation
Helpful (3)

review_title: Takes a while to make an impact
pros: Great culture overall, the employees are almost all easy to work with and very bright. Everyone is very passionate about the industry. The company is also well positioned to take on challenges in that the utility of the future will face. Exelon also offers a ton of flexibility for employees to move to various areas of the company in order to broaden their experience in preparation for advancement.
cons:
It seemed to me that it takes many many years of experience at the company before your opinions are valued or before you can have significant impact. The industry and company are massive and complex and do take significant time to gain expertise. Also, decisions seem to primarily be made at the extremely senior SVP and Chief levels, with very little influence or room for innovation at all happening in middle management or even Director level. Very interesting and innovative work can be had in Strategy and Constellation Ventures and special projects teams.
Advice to Management
With the future of the utility very uncertain and significant innovation still waiting in this industry, try to involve younger generations in new projects and ideation. Look also to eliminate waste of paper pushing in lower and mid management positions - there are vast inefficiencies that if eliminated can open up doors for mid level employees to actually contribute to growth rather than processes and procedures.
Helpful

pros: the catered lunches can be really good, which helps, considering women in the company have to watch every penny
cons:
Women make a lot less than men. The company throws around a lot of smoke and mirrors and claim that women make 98% of what a man does, but it's not anywhere near the truth. Any woman down in the ranks can tell you they are doing a man's job for a lot less and still being treated like an admin. The company talks about how much money it saves by cutting back on various expenditures, but they are saving the most money by paying women less than a man. Parking in the new BHQ building is now up to over $200/month! Who can afford to pay that when are cost of living expenses aren't even enough for a tank of gas every month.
Advice to Management
Don't think that we don't notice and that there isn't a lot of dissention within the female ranks. Start paying attention to us or we're only going to start getting louder. Stop paying the (male) CEO millions and millions per year while we women are trying to raise kids or just live. We're spreading the word that Exelon isn't the place to be for women. Don't think we are buying into the lie that we are making anywhere near what a man makes. We talk about salaries and we know the real deal. Stop trying to just look good from a PR angle as it's not working. Show us real respect and not lip service.

review_title: You aren't an employee but a possession
pros: they hire people from military
cons:
I don't even know where to begin. HR is full of snakes and they try to hire you for as little as possible while they pay the CEO over $100 million a year. They talk about cost containment and then send out company memos talking about how profits have gone up and how many millions they have saved. They saved that money on the backs of their employees, the ones who are down in the real world doing the work. You are expected to give up your life in order to meet deadlines.
Advice to Management
Learn your place. You employ us, you don't own us. We could drop dead on the job and it would just be a case of finding someone else to do our workloads while you schmooze on the golf course. Show some respect. Treat your femail employees as something other than glorified admins. Fire the CEO and spread his wealth among the workers. Fire the whole HR team and get people with integrity to do their jobs. These 5 star reviews are fake half the time to keep ratings up, but we all know better.

review_title: It matters which business unit you work for
pros: Exelon is huge, with incredible resources at it's disposal. The benefits package is pretty damn good. The flexible work schedule is great. The pay is actually decent, even if it feels a bit low in an Oil Business town like Houston.
cons:
Various business units go through cycles of growth and "optimization." Some years, you're overworked because you're migrating systems due to an acquisition. Others, you're overworked because "optimization and efficiency" measures have decimated the contractor workforce.
Advice to Management
Mind your culture! The ebb and flow of business will never change, but if you give your people a mission, make them feel important and valued and part of a family, then everyone will succeed. Leave the drama and political maneuvering out of it.
Helpful

review_title: Not Worth Your Time or Mine
pros:
seriously dedicated people on some teams
good with trying the latest technology
can work from home if necessary
cons:
it's not what you know it's who you know
money is spent on white elephants and you are the one forced to make it work
the management gets more clueless and lost the higher you go
women can be treated as second class citizens, sometimes by other women
Advice to Management
Chris Crane, you gave an interview with the Baltimore Sun about making a commitment to this city, but what about your own employees? You need to stop relying on massaged data and statistics and take a look around to see why so many good people are leaving. I used to get to work early and stay late, and now I walk through the door of that new highrise building we work in at the last minute and leave as soon as I can. Groups of us leave for work lunches and happy hours only to talk about how our job searches elsewhere are going. Stop thinking that it's about looking good, because appearances are very deceptive. I couldn't wait to start my job at Exelon, but reality set in and I saw the real deal. Also, do something about treating our women better. I have personally apologized to a female coworker on at least two occasions because of the way they were disrespected in meetings. I was embarrassed to witness what I saw.

pros: After moving on from entry level engineering position, the pay is very very competitive. There is also a large opportunity to learn beyond your specific engineering focus which is great for a career. For example, even if you're electrical, you might be expected to learn mechanical systems which is great for development. There is also a lot of opportunities for growth if you put a lot of work in and make your goals clear.
cons:
While the pay can be good, the leadership in the company seems to struggle with decision making.
Specific site leadership is the same, and is constantly using general company "propaganda" terms and goals and then making decisions that contradict those. 
Engineers are also used as an "unlimited resource" due to no work hour rules and salary pay. Which means they will put as much work on you as they can, and expect long work hours. 
All in all, this is a good place to start your career as a new engineer, you'll learn how to work hard and it looks good on a resume, but with sacrifices in other areas (like personal life).
Advice to Management
Recognize that the incoming employees desire more than just money. They desire work life balance and other benefits, and leadership that cares about their well being rather than just the work.
Helpful (4)

Spends billions buying another energy company and building a new building in Baltimore and then says they are too broke to give you a proper raise
Worst HR department I have ever experienced in my life uninformed and unprofessional
They act like they are the only game in town, but I have two interviews later this month with other Fortune 100 companies
Advice to Management
Invest in the people you pretend to care so much about and then you won't have to wonder why we are leaving. It's unacceptable to pay the CEO millions and millions and waste money by the hundreds of thousands of dollars and then say you are too broke to pay your employees fairly. Stop acting like we are possessions and not employees.

review_title: Stay Away as We're Leaving ASAP
pros: Great place if you are obese, as they are always having eating contests and cooking challenges.
cons:
Where to start? We're also so demoralized that some departments are having interviews to see how they can get people to stay. You can't fill out a survey there because nothing is anonymous so they will track you down if you say anything negative. It's a men's club. If you hang out with the right people, you get a promotion. If you are a woman or a man who prefers going home instead of drinking with the boys, you pay the price. They spend tons of money on things that don't matter, such as entertaining lavishly but plead cost optimization when you ask for more money to do your job. No one volunteers for anything, because you're not rewarded. Then they try to have team building exercises and wonder why no one is interested in participating. We're all leaving because unless you're a man who already has drinking buddies there, you have nothing coming.

Not good for your health, mentally or physically. They have health challenges, but then they turn around and have cookoffs and wing eating challenges. 

They are all about talent acquisition instead of talent retention. When you join, they make sure to lowball you and no one is allowed to know their salary range, so of course, you get the short end of the stick.
Advice to Management
That shiny, tall new building with Exelon's name on it that we're all moving into? You're not going to have any "talent" to occupy the place unless you work on "talent" retention. You can afford a new building but plead poverty when it comes to the things that matter, your employees.
Helpful (10)

pros:
Great networking opportunities
Awesome Intern events
Collaboration with other departments 
Volunteer Sessions
Professional Development Groups
cons:
Majority of the team I was assigned to was fairly new. Whenever they would make mistakes they would blame it on the interns. Throughout the entire program I constantly asked for feedback on tasks in which I was assigned. In result i was ALWAYS told by team members "everything is great" and "you're doing a good job" only to find out team members were bashing me to my manager. She never came to me for verification of these accusations either. When I went to her I was accused of being defensive. She (my manager) never showed any interest in me, or my career goals she didn't even ask what they were. Nor did she ever interact with me if she didn't have to. Common hallway interactions she would avoid eye contact at all cost and go out of her way to avoid a conversation with me. My third day with the company she asked me "how I managed to land this position". She also made inappropriate remarks to me quite often which lead me to develop anxiety while at work. Everything I learned about the company I learned from people I met at Intern networking events. My team would invite me to meetings, I would attend and my manager would tell me that I don't need to be there. Why invite me only to kick me out how do you expect me to learn anything. This was a terrible experience.
Advice to Management
Every opportunity you had, you verbally reminded me that I was a diversity hire. Your comments made my time with the company extremely uncomfortable. It would have been nice to see you more invested in my growth and development. Don't bother to accept interns if you cant be bothered with them. Lead by example, the team treated me the same way that you did.
Helpful

review_title: Nicely covers the bottom tier of Maslow's Heirarchy
pros:
- Very competitive benefits package, which has also been available to GLBT partners for a while now.
- Because it is both *huge* and diversified, the company manages to weather market volatility better than some.
cons:
- Because it is both *huge* and diversified, the company doesn't really have a mission that employees can at least pretend to embrace. "Delivering shareholder value" just doesn't inspire positive culture.
- There are more contractors than employees, which insulates employees from market volatility, but sometimes results in dramatic headcount fluctuations.
Advice to Management
So few people seem passionate about working for the company... just lucky to be stably employed with decent benefits. That's great, in a sense, but people need a story - a mission - to help foster a positive culture in the company (as opposed to indifferent)

review_title: Operations... At least I can pay off my student loans.
pros:
The only reason you should ever become an operator is if you only care about money. Yes it's very easy to pull in 130-145,000 with a couple of overtime days. 

The people who work here are also very cool.
cons:
Everything else.

The hours... Rotating 12 hour schedule (DuPont) google it. You do get 7 days off, but those days and nights you work 12 hours you just come home and want to sleep because of how tired you are. Basically 24 hour days.

Nuclear politics and regulations.
Sweet mother of god where do I even start. An operator is the bottom of the totem pole at a nuclear plant. If something breaks they will find a way to pin it on you and convince you that you're incompetent. I feel like whoever came up with "human performance" came straight off a nuclear submarine and into HR.

Run.
Advice to Management
Incorporate psychology into your human performance ideals. Understand that drilling an idea into someone's head over and over again will only help them remember it. But this idea will neither be respected nor properly implemented.

pros:
Salary and Benefits: The nuclear industry pays extremely well with performance bonuses, annual pay raises, and overtime/outage pay. Discounted stock purchase and good 401k matching. There are also fitness and health reimbursements available.

Coworkers: Smart, talented, hardworking people. Good mix of people, from the Shop workers to the Operators and Engineers. White/blue collar mix. Casual dress/work environment.

Interesting Work: Unique industry. Very technically involved.
cons:
Workload: Salaried for 40 hours a week, but a more realistic number is 50-60. Managers typically have 10 hour days that may limit employee oversight.

Additional Duty: Responsible for standing emergency response teams that limit your weekend activities (no drinking, travel limitations). Outage coverage means 12hr shiftwork for ~1 month per year.

Regulation: If you want to "change the world" then you need to work for Elon Musk. The NRC and government regulates everything in the nuke power industry. Conservative thinking and risk management are mandatory cultural adaptations.
Helpful (1)

review_title: One of the best and most exciting employers I ever had!
pros: Diversity in qualified people, team work, regulatory compliance beyond other industries, perks, great cafeteria and gym onsite, exposure to the best people in their respective fields from all walks of life and all over the world. cons:
Nepotism and favoritism still exists. No program to utilize talented people who for one reason or another can no longer perform tasks of original position. Establish a program to utilize your most important capital in new ways, i.e. Loyal employees who have given all for the company. pros: Very good benefits and compensation. The company is diversified across both regulated utility operations and deregulated generation and wholesale trading and retail supply/risk management activities.
cons:
The company has an extremely bloated management / corporate structure that in the current low priced gas and power environment is not sustainable in my view. They are a company that probably should be acquired - the potential cost savings by eliminating a bunch of corporate jobs that add little to no value would be easy pickings. 

The company cares so much about diversity, that it doesn't always promote based on merit in my view.

The culture is one of title and hierarchy meaning more than competence, ability and work ethic.
Advice to Management
Stop being so politically correct. Figure out a strategy or you will be acquired and will be unemployed. You should probably gut a lot of your top and mid to high end managers (SVP, VP, Director level jobs) and you might actually be able to make money on the deregulated side of the business.

advice_to_mgmt: Stop being so politically correct. Figure out a strategy or you will be acquired and will be unemployed. You should probably gut a lot of your top and mid to high end managers (SVP, VP, Director level jobs) and you might actually be able to make money on the deregulated side of the business.

pros: Pay and benefits are good. People are generally helpful and friendly.
cons:
Design engineering at the nuclear plants has nothing to do with classical design. All our design was completed by Sargent & Lundy in the 70's and 80's. We're just maintaining everything. In your interview they'll tell you about all this great stuff you'll be doing, but you'll soon realize that the challenging, fast-paced work environment you desire does not exist at Exelon. Vast majority of work is slow-paced administrative work. Information takes forever to obtain because of the lack of technology. Drawings haven't been updated since the 70's, very little on CAD, no BIM models for power plants, everything is on paper floating somewhere among the countless unorganized shelves, filing cabinets and senior engineer's desks. Management is not receptive of new ideas from the younger generation although they encourage "out-of-the-box" thinking. Nuke plants are dominated by former Navy who bring their military "yes man" demeanor to Exelon management. They are also not very receptive or comfortable with working with women. Middle managers are worthless babysitters and upper management rarely disagrees with the guy above them. Exelon and its subsidiaries are regulated utility companies. There's little incentive to change anything or improve workplace efficiency because of the ICC energy auctions and company budgeting. Have extra money at the end of the year? Why bother updating our out-dated training programs or data management when we can build another conference room with expensive projectors that never get used. Unless you work at corporate in Chicago or Naperville, then you'll probably work in the middle-of-nowhere. No overtime pay. Outages require 6, 10 hour days and no weekends off. Cannot drink or travel one week of each month when you're "on duty" and might be called in.
Advice to Management
Allow change! Stop saying you want new ideas when you provide no outlet for engineers to express and address them. Stop labeling positions as "Design" when only maintenance is being done. Out-source work to get physical files transferred to computer-searchable data. Job feels working for a government jobs program.
Helpful (2)

employee_status: Corporate Engineering in Kennet Sq, PA
pros: Benefits are very competitive and tend to be better than what you will find at other large electric utilities. Company leadership is forward-thinking and creative when examining ways to strengthen and grow company. Company has clear desire to retain current good employees by making ample internal opportunities available. The company commitment to Individual development is head and shoulders above what I have seen elsewhere.
cons:
At times, the workload can be significant. This is to be expected in a dynamic business environment, but employees should understand this coming in so that a false sense of work/life balance (40 hour weeks every week) is not created. The work needs to be completed to support the business and employees are compensated accordingly.
Advice to Management
The company is a proud company with a history of leading the industry. Saying that, pride is considered one of the seven deadly sins for a reason. Over time, too much pride in past accomplishments can lead to a reluctance to look externally at what others are doing (better). Eventually, performance will plateau and then decline if the only source of ideas are those generated internally. Look for innovation both inside and outside the company. Many external entities have much to offer.
Helpful

pros: The pay and benefits are very good. In some business units there is a good deal of flexibility about work location and flexible work options such as work from home which fosters improved work life balance. Because Exelon is a large and diverse company there are good opportunities for career growth. Working for such a large and nationally recognized company provides a certain degree of job and financial stability that you can’t get from a smaller company or a startup. There is a strong emphasis on innovation throughout the company while at the same time remaining a stable and secure energy producing and providing company that continues to expand in the Energy market.
cons:
In lieu of in place promotions, one has to apply for a job opening to be promoted. This isn't all bad though because this promotes diversification of one's career and broadens you exposure and experience. 

While there is a high degree of focus on innovation and creativity, being such a large, diverse, well tenured company, change doesn't always happen quickly. If you are looking for a startup feel, fast paced, quickly changing, rapidly evolving company, Exelon may not be the best fit for you; however, those who demonstrate creativity and devise innovative solutions are recognized and appreciated.
Helpfu

review_title: From Intern to Happy New Hire!
pros: This company is invested in your development and growth on an ongoing bases. There are opportunities to progress upward and across the company, The Flexibility (pay and time), PAY, Benefits (Too many to name), THE PEOPLE (I've worked for Corporate Security and currently work in Commercial IT, loved both teams). The relationships between Senior Management and employees, the culture is relaxed. There is an interest to get to know you pass your career objectives. They have positions for wherever you are in your career. You can go afar as you please (it's up to you). Location, the scenery and you're near everything.
cons:
I personally haven't found one. However,this is not so much a con as it is advice. I've had 4 managers since I've start on my current team. Adaptability is highly suggested. There's actually a lot of new processes, projects, changes in business structure, mergers and etc. Always contribute and give feedback to improve that when necessary. There's never a dull moment.
Advice to Management
Continue to create a very pleasant working environment. Continue to training and provide opportunities for personal and professional development.

pros: Out of the three previous companies I worked for out of college hands down this is the best company I have worked for. The company really cares about its employees. The pay is above industry standard and everyone in the company is bonus eligible which you don't see very often from other companies. Exelon has great benefits, generous compensation and gives back to the community and donates and participates in several fundraising events. Exelon has the most friendly environment at a large company I have ever seen. Everyone says hi in the hallways and introduces themselves. I really enjoy my team and co-workers here at work which makes it enjoyable to come to work.
cons:
There can be a lot of work at times and can be a bit overwhelming but Exelon does encourage a work/life balance. It can be hard to move up in the organization since openings don't open very often (need to have a better career mapping for employees).
Advice to Management
For your top performing E02s and E03s have career mapping and goals for this level to achieve the next step in their careers other than that keep recognizing and making employees feel appreciated it goes a long way.

review_title: Very low pay and it's all about statistics, not people
pros: Great benefits if you actually make enough money to use them
cons:
The benefits offered are great but you can't afford to use them because your salary doesn't cover anything but bills (if that). HR doesn't care about people, only making sure they look good on sites like this one. You can make a lot less with an MBA or another advanced degree than someone who only has a high school degree. Not enough money to invest in savings, retirement, or any of their other plans. HR will lowball you as much as possible. You need an inside track or a friend who is in management to make a decent salary. The company has no problem spending money when they feel it is relevant, but are quick to plead poverty otherwise. They put up videos on YouTube for recruiting purposes but don't believe a word. It's all about statistics, not about investing in people.
Advice to Management
Realize you are working with actual human beings here with mortgages to pay just like you are.

review_title: Minority Senior Engineer (over 10 years with BGE/20+ years in Engrg)
pros: The utility industry as a whole is a very stable work environment, BGE will be celebrating 200 years in 2016. As for the work culture here, I can say there are pockets of exceptional leaders (most of whom are retiring) and pockets of those individuals that should not be leaders and are extremely toxic. Our HR department is well aware of these individuals and for whatever reason do nothing to correct the issues. It is sad really, as I have watched very seasoned and talented individuals leave this company due to these toxic individuals. My advice to anyone looking at this company for employment is to do your research and ask someone within the organization where to work and who to work for....avoid the drama and possibility of having to look for another job (internally or externally).
cons:
As for diversity and inclusion...it is merely a façade that Exelon "owns" and mandates down to the business entities (nice try but this is not working). I am a seasoned female engineer and can say with great disappointment, that we are not even close to operating in the 21st Century (there are only 16 female engineers @ BGE at the Individual Contributor Level- this is 0.4% of the BGE employee base....wow, really?). As mentioned above, there are pockets of toxic leaders in this company that do not recognize work-life balance nor the needs of single/widowed parents...if these leaders could realize that having young children is such a blessing and truly a short period in ones life, they could retain and grow very valuable company assets. I have heard of disheartening stories within this company that young mothers have been forced to leave the company because their leaders did not allow flexible working hours for childcare and/or health issues....truly disappointing and understanding why FMLA exists. 

Other issues exist with the "less seasoned" generation's attitude of "entitlement" and beliefs that they should be senior employees/leaders after only <5 years of service/work experience...BGE is bypassing and losing valuable employees/leaders because they pacify this generation's mentality and promote these people to incompetence.
Advice to Management
Open your eyes and start "walking the talk". You conduct employee surveys and do not correct the issues nor do you take a deep enough dive into what the issues truly are (the survey is too vague). Read the posts on this site...they speak loudly to work-life issues, how employees are treated, etc.....If you do not start to truly lead with integrity, then this company will suffer as others have historically done, like General Motors...Exelon has Union employees at PECO & COMED for a reason....do you really want that to happen to BGE?
Helpful (2)
Exelon Response
July 14, 2015 – Sr Analyst, National and Strategic Programs
Thank you for taking the time to comment. We are dedicated to creating a respectful and inclusive workplace where every employee has the opportunity to grow and contribute at her or his greatest potential. The company has made enormous progress in this area, but still has more work to do. Employee feedback is essential to making sure we get it right. If you are willing to provide additional insight, we would appreciate it. Please email CorporateTalentAcquisition@exeloncorp.com

pros: In keeping with the 20 word minimum requirement, the only pros of working at Exelon are the museum discounts and a steady paycheck.
cons:
Everyone who works here is antisocial and have no social life outside of work. The traditional work/life balance is a lie. It’s a high-stress work environment that leads to serious health problems and work errors. I understand the need to have work done well, however, people make petty complaints about you to your boss. This leads to a cycle of micromanagement and a soul-crushing process of your eventual demise.
Advice to Management
Convey appreciation of your employees and do not force your way on anyone. Constantly correcting or second guessing undercuts confidence and creativity. Hear their reasons for their actions and don’t make assumptions. Delegate responsibility based on employee’s strengths and not on seniority.

Benefits are great (PTO, Flexible work schedules and remote work, Medical Ins).
Great, modern office space in the Chicago loop location.
cons:
Training and growth opportunities are lacking above a Sr Analyst (Sr Developer) level in the IT department. 
Although they talk a lot about work life balance, it doesn't come to fruition due to the constant downsizing and resistance to hiring new FTEs.

Practice what you preach with emphasis on training and work-life balance. 
Provide more opportunities for inter department transfers to allow employees to grow at least laterally and learn other businesses to help with job satisfaction.

pros: Job stability. Benefits; medical, dental, etc. Pay is above average.
cons:
Can be mandated to work overtime anytime; can't really plan activities on your days off. Will work nights for quite a number of years until you gain seniority. The management doesn't care about your personal life or your opinion. Seems like the rules are always changing. Procedures are in place but unfortunately left to personal interpretation. Equipment is old or broken; the environment is reactive instead of proactive. If in security dept., very difficult to transfer to another department, even if you have experience or qualifications. It's a "who you know" environment. Lots of cliques and seems like a lot of buddy-buddy environment. If you are what's considered an "outsider" your career will not flourish.
Advice to Management
Treat employees like human beings. After all, they are your greatest asset.

review_title: Excellent Company with Endless Opportunities for Employees
pros: I have been employed with this organization for several years and each year I recommit myself as an employee. I have the ability to give input on the shape and direction of my department, my leadership team places an emphasis on work-life balance and the on-the job training is spot on. I feel that I am paid competitively for my experience and there are various incentives for strong on the job performance. I continue to learn about the industry as a whole and I am constantly given guidance on the strategy of the organization by senior leadership.
cons:
While I am a very happy employee it can be challenging at time when team resources are not there to meet operational goals. I can say however that my leadership team listens and responds in kind if/when this occurs.

Senior leadership should continue to communicate directly with employees on our overall corporate strategy and the state of the business. As an employee who plans on a long career with the company there should be a continued focus on personal development above and beyond functional goals.

pros: Exelon as a company is great to work for in many ways. Excellent pay and benefits and I work with amazing people. There are so many intelligent people who work here and everyone is always so willing to answer questions and help. The friendly culture here is really a great thing as I came from a company where employess would not even say hello in the elevator or restroom, so the fact that we do here without it being such a chore is a fabulous breath of fresh air! I work here with pride and can smile when people ask me where I work and what I do. It's a neat industry to work for.
cons:
Desperately need job advancement opportunities for mid-level employees. We are top and bottom heavy, and not enough opportunities in the middle. Need more lead opportunities for some to get more leadership experience. Work/life balance is a huge issue. We desperately need to get on the "telecommuting" train like the rest of corporate america. I understand at the sites that's difficult if you are in a plant role, but support roles should be able to more easily telecommute. It should not be something that is frowned upon. It should also be acceptable to have jean Friday's every Friday no matter what floor or work location you are on. Such a basic perk could make so many employees so happy!
Advice to Management
We spend a lot of time criticizing here and not complimenting. I can say from experience, a basic compliment goes a LONG way. A high five or a thank you for your efforts motivates employees so much more than always saying work harder, work faster, work more, it's never enough. We need to acknowlege more often what amazing things our employees do and you'll see even more amazing things to follow!
Helpful (1)
Exelon Response

review_title: Overall, a pretty good place to work.
pros: Lots of different career opportunities, all within one company. There are plenty of advancement opportunities. Good benefits. Employees are generally supported by their managers.
cons:
Exelon is a very large company, and the individual companies that fall under Exelon are fragmented. They do not all receive the same benefits, nor do they all operate the same way. Depending on which type of position you have with Exelon, work life balance can vary from good to non-existent. Benefits package is diminishing regularly.
Advice to Management
Though some effort is being made to address the quickly eroding workforce (through retirements), more should be done. The remaining workforce cannot perform all of the work and also train the replacements. Re-hiring retirees as contractors should be a short-term solution, not a permanent solution. Eventually, the retirees that receive traditional pensions will run out, at which point coming back as a contractor will hold little value to the retirees. Keep a strong benefits package to continue to draw the right talent.

review_title: Great culture makes it a great company!
pros: Most of my experience has been in the utilities at Exelon and I have found that the leaders are truly interested in the employees and support work/life balance. Much responsibility is given to employees, making it a challenging, but interesting place to work. There is tremendous opportunity for growth and advancement, all of which is highly encouraged and supported by management. Special projects, temporary assignments, rotations, and shadowing opportunities are all available to let employees test the waters for different roles and see if different roles and positions would interest them. The pay and benefits (great vacation allotment) are really competitive too! Also, the company is very flexible, at least in the non-field positions, in terms of work flex schedules or from remote locations.
cons:
As Exelon continues to grow and expand through mergers and acquisitions, the change process associated with aligning companies can be a little tough.
Advice to Management
Recognize each business unit for its own contributions, continue to seek feedback from employees and be considerate when requiring employees to work long hours into the night.

review_title: Exelon is a great comapny that invests in its employees.
pros:
Exelon offers its employees many growth opportunities. The company has a great development program. When I first accepted a management position they sent me to a 1 month development program to develop my leadership skills. I have worked in many areas of the industry including instrument and controls, operations, mechanical maintenance, and generation dispatch. The company has always been supportive of all of my goals. When I expressed that I wanted to work in our commodities trading business unit I was allowed to shadow trade floor operations. Exelon also supported my goal by funding a significant portion of my MBA. I currently work to coordinate our physical position to support the traders in all of our regions.

Exelon capitalizes on diversity. I am a perfect example. I have worked in several types of plants in many different roles. Exelon uses my diverse background to help our commodities organization to work more coherently with our generation fleet. 

Exelon works to support the communities we serve. The company is actively engaged in volunteer programs. I have personally had the opportunity to work with students at technical colleges and environmental groups though my affiliation with Exelon. 

Exelon is well balanced. We have a good mix of regulated utilities, retail power and merchant generation. This mix provides endless opportunities for employees that are willing to try new things. The company is aggressively looking to expand which brings more opportunities. 

Exelon has a great benefits package. We have a pension, 401K, employee stock purchase program, wellness programs, many types of clubs and social groups, great health benefits, and great vacation policies. 

I love working here. I have actively recruited personal friends to work for the company.
cons:
One of the Cons at Exelon is that I work a lot. If you are looking to work a forty hour week this may not be the place for you. That being said, Exelon and my immediate supervisor have been very supportive of working remotely or at satellite location to improve my work life balance.

Another potential Con is that the company is very widespread. Sometimes to achieve your goals you may be required to relocate.
Advice to Management
One piece of advice that I would offer senior leadership is to continue to work to ensure that employees understand all of the opportunities that are available to them. I have encountered coworkers that do not know how to use their Individual Development Plan to maximize their potential.
Helpful

review_title: You will never be bored working for Exelon!
pros: There are numerous challenges to tackle - and the only limit is your imagination! Senior management encourages engagement, new ideas, and genuinely trying to make things better for our employees and customers. The value for safety is paramount - and this is stressed all the time. If you want to make a difference and make things better - you will have a good experience at Exelon - you will never be bored! Our industry is in the midst of a lot of change - so we need to keep fresh thinking and new ideas - and need people to keep an eye to the future. Doing work in different parts of the business is encouraged - so you can move around and find numerous development opportunities.
cons:
Because we are such a big company - it is hard for all parts of the business to know what each other is doing - we tend to work in silos too often. 

A part of the job is being part of a 24-7-365 company that provides a vital service - so it also means that you will be working at times that you may not want to (holidays, etc.). 

We also need to do a better job of onboarding new employees to set them up for maximum success.
Advice to Management
Always stay engaged with your people - set them up for success - and learn their major barriers to success so you can remove obstacles.

review_title: Change your career without changing companies
pros: Exelon has a number of subsidiary companies, each with various positions and opportunities. Want to work in Marketing for a couple of years? Go for it. Now you say you want to work with political stakeholders? No problem. Wait…..how about trying your hand at managing a Call Center? We’ve got a spot open. There are very few companies out there that allow you to move from department to department, career to career, without having to jump ship. In fact, learning new skill sets is HIGHLY encouraged. I really appreciate the fact that I can move around the company every few years and try my hand at something new and exciting.
cons:
Rightfully so, the company's number one priority is to keep the lights on for our customers. Meaning, if there is a storm or some type of adverse event, EVERYONE is expected to pitch in and help mobilize crews to restore power. We refer to this work as "storm duty". Thus, if you are "on duty" when a storm hits, you do not work your 9-5 job and instead work to restore service. This could easily mean 12 to 16 hour days depending on the gravity of the destruction. Plus, you still have to make up all the work left undone at your 9-5.
Helpful
Exelon Response

review_title: Great Opportunities for someone looking for a place to succeed
pros:
1) I really enjoy the challenges that are presented. I have been able to move around in my department and to different departments to get a better feel for the organization. 
2) Special projects outside of your day-to-day experience. If you hate doing the same thing over and over, that won't happen working at this company. I receive great opportunities for new experiences whenever possible. This has lead to great networking oppotunities in the industry and in the fleet. 
3) The benefits are much better working here. The pay is on the order of 85th percentile for recent graduates. Vacation is also very good, we get holidays plus two to four weeks standard (depending on your entry level) and rolling over unused days is also possible.
4) This company invests in you. There is always additional training offered to specialize in your job or for more general requirements such as root cause training. You can pick which training courses you want to take to be more efficient at your job along with standard courses for you and your collegues. 
5) The single best thing about working for this company is that they address feedback. This industry feeds on critical feedback and makes it a cornerstone for improvement.
cons:
1) Work-Life balance needs to be strived for to obtain. I wouldn't expect that a 40 hour week would ever be considered normal, unless you are in the union. More often than not, expect 50 hour weeks. 
2) This is a very fast-paced environment, so things happen rapidly.
3) Depending on your job, it will be expected that if there are issues on off-hours including holidays and weekends that you are there to support if required.
Advice to Management
Continue the focus on the basics. I am very pleased with upper management.

review_title: Very Solid Company wih typical corporate workings
pros:
-- solid company in a dependable industry
-- flexible work schedules in professional roles
-- Compensation is actively benchmarked against industry, so pay is (by design) average for large corporations. But since the benchmark is against large corporations, when compared to all available job options in the area the pay is actually pretty decent in my opinion.
-- well defined policies for EVERYTHING
-- lots of room to move around the company, I have gotten to rotate to new job every 1-3 years. Or you could stay in the same job the whole time if you prefer.
-- Easy for "high performers" to get ahead and progress in career without changing companies
cons:
-- Benefits actively benchmarked against industry, so benefits are (by design) average, I've seen much better benefits in gov or other private sector jobs, but our benefits are not the worst.
-- Work Life balance is tough, in order to be a "high performer" you are going to be working about 20% overtime
-- Change Management is non existant, you are lucky if you get an email about a change that is coming and will affect you. The company could do a much better jobs with communicating change.
Advice to Management
remove stock holder protection feature from annual bonus, while I understand the logic from a shareholder perspective it is very demoralizing to employees. This options caps the bonus payout of the child company’s based on the performance of the stock price for the parent company (exelon). The result is that employees in the child company’s feel no connection between their bonus and their actual efforts because the bonuses are often capped based on things out of the employee’s control. A child company can have a great year but wind up not getting rewarded because the stock price did not do well which could be completely driven by market forces outside of the child company's control.
Helpful
